summary: The project manager opens the meeting by stating that they will address functional design and then going over the agenda. The industrial designer gives his presentation, explaining how remote controls function and giving personal preference to a clear, simple design that upgrades the technology as well as incorporates the latest features in chip design. The interface specialist gives her presentation next, addressing the main purpose of a remote control. She pinpoints the main functions of on/off, channel-switching, numbers for choosing particular channels, and volume; and also suggests adding a menu button to change settings such as brightness on the screen. She gives preference to a remote that is small, easy to use, and follows some conventions. The group briefly discusses the possibility of using an LCD screen if cost allows it, since it is fancy and fashionable. The marketing expert presents, giving statistical information from a survey of 100 subjects. She prefers a remote that is sleek, stylish, sophisticated, cool, beautiful, functional, solar-powered, has long battery life, and has a locator. They discuss the target group, deciding it should be 15-35 year olds. After they talk about features they might include, the project manager closes the meeting by allocating tasks.
actions: When they return to their desks they will complete a questionaire, do a summary, and send the project manager their powerpoint presentations. The interface specialist will look at the user interface concept. The marketing expert will be watching trends (possibly relating to voice recognition). The industrial designer will look into components
problems: The group is interested in voice recognition- this is an option they will have to explore further before deciding whether to use it.

ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant2hBcComponents_design..2.ppt ------------ Components Design Presented by: , Industrial Designer Method Findings Personal Preferences ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant2hBcWorking_design..2.ppt ------------ Working Design Presented by: Gaurav Malhotra, Industrial Designer Method Identification of components Feedback for constraints Integration with other requirements Update design. Findings How a remote control works Components and processes Teletext outdated! The remote control should only be used for the television Uniqeness (colour and slogan) Components Personal Preferences Clear design Possibility for upgrade Latest technology ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant3hBcInterface_concept..2.ppt ------------ Interface Concept Presented by: Maarika Traat User Interface Designer Definition User interface: The aspects of a computer system or program which can be seen (or heard or otherwise perceived) by the human user, and the commands and mechanisms the user uses to control its operation and input data. E.g. Shape, size, buttons, voice-recognition, Colour, etc. Method Research the interfaces of related products, mainly on the internet. Analyse their user friendliness Assess their appearance Decide which features to incorporate in the design of our product. Findings In the case of most of the remote controls the interface consists of a clutter of button functions, colors, and forms. This inconsistent use of interface is confusing and doesn't improve the use of the product. New user interface component voice recognition (record up to 80 voice samples) A spinning wheel with LC display A scroll button with integrated push button (such as in modern computer mouse) at the side of the remote Latest developments of the manufacturing division of our company programmable speech speaker unit add on to voice recognition Personal Preferences Keep it small Keep it simple Include voice recognition Standard major buttons Other function via menu on screen ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant3hBcTechnical_functions.ppt ------------ Technical Functions Design Presented by: Maarika Traat, User Interface Designer Method Search the web for inspiration from similar devices. Think about user needs and desires Think about the main function of the remote control Findings The function of a remote control is to send messages to the television set. "switch on "switch off "switch to next channel "switch to channel 9 "turn volume up" Findings The present standard seems to be that besides TV functions the remotes also have functions to operate a VSR. They do not seem to be able to handle the requirements of DVD players. Personal Preferences Keep it small Easy to use The must have buttons On/off Channel numbers, next/previous channel Volume Menu for more complicated functions (e.g. brightness) Do we want to incorporate Video and DVD related functions? - (No: last minute update on the project spec.) ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant4hBcEvaluation..5.ppt ------------ Evaluation criteria Presented by: Cat Marketing Expert Method Preparing the evaluation of the new design This should be done using a 7 point scale where 1 is TRUE and 7 is FALSE, as regarding the design meeting a certain criteria. This is based on the collection of criteria on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and the marketing strategy of the Real Reaction electronics company. Aims The remote control should: be attractive to look at match the operating behaviour of the user be locatable be intuitive have an ergonomic design to reduce risk of RSI have voice control be technologically innovative put fashion into electronics Evaluation ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant4hBcFunctional_requirements..4.ppt ------------ Functional Requirements Presented by: Cat, Market Expert Method Usability lab observed remote control use amongst 100 subjects, who then filled in a questionnaire. They investigated: - What the users think about the look and feel of current remote controls. The biggest frustrations of using remote controls Speech recognition and LCD screens in remote controls. Findings Users dislike the look and feel of current remote controls. 75% of users find most remote controls ugly 80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user 75% of users said they zap a lot 50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons Findings The graph shows that the most predominant uses of the remote is for Chanel Selection Teletext (including flipping pages) Volume Control 9 9 10 10 2 1.5 3 Frustrations Remote controls are often lost somewhere in the room (50%) It takes too much time to learn how to use a new remote control (34%) Remote controls are bad for RSI (26%) Voice Recognition? Personal Preferences Sleek Stylish Sophisticated Functional Minimalist Long battery life Solar power Locator (clap and then it beeps?) The remote control should only be used for the television Uniqeness (colour and slogan) Components Personal Preferences Clear design Possibility for upgrade Latest technology ES2006docs.ES2006scen.participant1hBcFinal.report.doc ------------ Final report Team: Jen (Project Manager) Cat (Marketing Expert) Gaurav (Industrial Design) Maarika (User Interface Design) Product: Television remote control Technical specifications: - internal simple battery - rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open - push buttons for power, and channels on front - push buttons for volume on side - LCD display with spinning wheel on inside for all other functions - advanced chip - voice recognition - separate locator to be attached to TV which will make remote beep - yellow banana-look with black buttons and grey company logo Product evaluation Attractive 7 Match operating behaviour 6 Be locatable 7 Be intuitive 5 Ergonomic to reduce RSI 6 Voice control 7 Technologically innovative 6 Put fashion in electronics 7 Average 6.4 Product description: An innovative, new-look TV remote control aimed at 15-35s, the Real Reaction product is in advance of trends in its spongy, vegetable-like look-and-feel. Combining a simple push button interface with the most popular remote commands and a flip-open LCD display and spinning wheel for advanced functionality, the product will revolutionise TV in this country and globally. Voice-recognition and built-in speaker increase ease-of-use and appeal to the designated target group, and the rubber casing and ergonomic design prevent damage and reduce the risk of RSI. Design process: The product was designed by a team of experts, each with his or her own speciality. The design process worked smoothly, interspersing individual work with regular meetings to consolidate knowledge gained and make key design decisions. Decision making was by consensus and all team members contributed to the process. The team worked well together and all minor differences were resolved through discussion. Technological resources (PowerPoint, laptops, whiteboards, email) were used appropriately and facilitated the smooth progression of the process. ES2006docs.ES2006scen.ProjectDocuments.Minutes.of-initial-meeting.doc ------------ Minutes of initial meeting Time: 11am, 28 Jan. 05 Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID) [ABSTRACT] The meeting functioned as an introduction to the team and the project. After an initial brief of the project, team members introduced themselves and their roles (see present above). The project finances were outlined, and then initial ideas for the product were briefly discussed. [DECISIONS] No decisions were made as this was an introductory meeting. The initialideas which were suggested by the marketing expert were agreed by the group - that we should go for a sleek look which fits with other products marketed by this company. This may involve having few or no buttons on the remote as many of these are rarely used anyway. The user interface designer cautioned against using a design which is too different from what consumers are used to as this will reduce the usability of the device. [ACTIONS] Actions to be taken: ID: the working design UID: the technical functions design ME: the user requirements specification PM: liaise with management, prepare minutes and next meeting ES2006docs.ES2006scen.ProjectDocuments.Minutes.of-meeting-2.doc ------------ Minutes of second meeting Time: 12:05pm, 28 Jan. 05 Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID) [ABSTRACT] This meeting brought together the initial individual work of the two designers and marketing expert. Each presented their ideas on working design, technical functions design and functional design respectively - presentations can be found in the project documents folder. Discussion followed, the result of which was a decision on target group and functionality [DECISIONS] Target group - 15-35 this implies incorporating voice recognition Design - small, sleek, sexy, but must follow some conventions for ease of use Functionality - volume, channel, power, menu, no teletext Locator perhaps to attach to TV TV only unless we can make a case to management that other things (eg video, DVD) should be supported as well, as most other models do this Voice recognition (we need to investigate implications of this before committing fully) would be great if it could recognise channels, not just numbers [PROBLEMS/ISSUES] Suggestions from management were incorporated with little trouble. Any extra functionality will make the chip bigger. This needs to be kept in mind during design. Likewise the cost implications of greater functionality. The possibility of an LCD screen was not explored. The design should be ergonomic to prevent RSI. [ACTIONS] ID: components concept UID: user interface concept ME: trend watching PM: liaise with management, keep team updated All to consider implications/feasibility ofincorporating voice recognition and keep our target group in mind when designing. ES2006docs.ES2006scen.ProjectDocuments.Minutes.of-meeting-3.doc ------------ Minutes of second meeting Time: 14:15pm, 28 Jan. 05 Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID) [ABSTRACT] This meeting focussed on the concepts of the remote control, including components, properties, materials, user interface and response to trends. Each team member presented their findingsand gave reasons for their preferred design choices. The meeting resulted in consensus on design specifications. [DECISIONS] Technical specifications: - internal simple battery - rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open - push buttons for power, volume and channels on outside - LCD display with spinning wheel on inside - voice recognition - advanced chip - sender and speaker if costs permit - 'fruit and vegetable' colours - orange, green, maybe red, yellow, purple - company colours can be incorporated in button design [ACTIONS] ID - look and feel design - model UID - user interface design - model ME - product evaluation PM final report
